description:
I lived in the mission near El Faro and went there from time time. The owner was a customer of mine in the real estate market and wanted to expand to a sit-down restaurant on Polk St. I encouraged him to keep a good thing going and he explanded El Faro into the financial district. It lasted a few years and now they are down to El Camino and the original Mission location.
      Business has been slow due to competition and at one time there were 6 or 7 employees turning out the orders. I always get a super burrito. I consider it among the best in the bay area. If you don't know any Spanish it may be difficult to order changes as many of the affected reviewers seem to demand. I take what they make and its good. With a cold beer or a soda its worth it. They have a clearly written menu describing what is in the particular dish. I cannot comment on the other meals because I am addicted to their super pork, beef, or chicken burritos. I said super, you have to get all the trimmings added to make them nice and juicy. The negative comments here are not justified but the result of poor education and upbringing from BAS-s. (bay area slobs) If you are dissatisfied, make your own Mexican food. Or go to Taco Bell. a good place too for fast food.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Usually I go in and ask for either burritos or tacos from the food that's already there sitting under the heaters and the food has been generally okay.
Yesterday I stopped by and asked for a chicken fajita burrito where they cooked the chicken and veggies together thinking it would be a more fresh option. 
Since they had a few other customers in I don't believe they waited for the chicken to be fully cooked and 15 minutes after I got home I was ill for the rest of the day.  
Don't get the chicken fajitas.
author: Albert Paris W.

description: Just ridiculous . Just for a cheese quesadilla $ 6-7 bucks . Really ???? Never going back to this place again . I have nothing against the place or the people there ,  the food it's ok but overpriced . I mean the quesadilla just had cheese no cream/ avocado/ just cheese .
author: Bretania E.

description:
Split a super breakfast burrito   

Eggs
Chorizo
Ham
Bacon
Cheese
Black beans

$10

No salsa bar
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Pathetic service. I spilled some coffee while waiting for the bus and the lady who works (or owns) here was standing outside so I asked if I can get one napkin from them . Her answer? 

It costs money. 

Of course I know this is a business and they are not obligated to offer me anything but if it weren't an emergency why would I ask napkin from you for no reason? Even I live two blocks away I would never come to this place.
author: Jared H.

description: I grew up in the mission and was fortunate to know the original owners of El Faro , I have had their food for decades always top notch !  However just a couple of weeks ago a friend of mine was in Concord Ca , told me he knew how much I love El Faro burritos & would pick me up 4 Super Burritos , When he arrived at my home which is in Nevada ,I was very disappointed , The beans looked from a can smashed up not whole , no flavor at all , the chicken was very small portion the rice was terrible and most of all I wanted extra Jalapenos like always order at El Faro in the mission .  TO THE NEW OWNERS SOMEONE GET OVER TO CONCORD  LOCATION ASAP BECAUSE THEY ARE RUINING THE 50 PLUS YEARS OF A GREAT RESTAURANT !!
author: Anthony M.

description: Terrible....I've been coming to this El Faro for 20+ years and its finally become SFed.. $15 for a burrito that was absolute rubbish. As an extra bonus they spilled horchata on the burrito to make it even worse. I guess its not their fault, everything past the SF City & County sign is a fail now.
author: Kris O.

description: Consistently awesome food and friendly service.  I have been eating here a few times a month for a couple years and have never once had a disappointing "bad day" burrito (which is something I can't say about any of my other favorite Mexican restaurants).  Prices have remained affordable, making it one of the only under-$10 lunch spots within an easy walking radius.  The carnitas is super in anything and I highly recommend the shrimp soft tacos.
author: Jeanne H.

description: This is one of the most upstanding burritos place in San Francisco, to say nothing of being the very first burrito place in San Francisco, and possibly in California.  Their breakfast burritos with chorizo are great!!
author: Tina G.

description: The breakfast is great. Chorizo burrito is my favorite in the Bay Area. Their lunch menu is also better then most places. Good prices.
author: Jordan L.

description:
El Faro might be the home of the Mission Burrito, but does not make it the best. 

I mean, sure, the burritos are huge. But they're mostly filled with rice! Plus, the beans are those really watery kind that have been sitting around for a while.

It's a decent burrito, but decent doesn't cut it in Cancun and Farolito's territory.
author: Casey S.

description: Best burritos ever! My family has been going here for over 40 years, shortly after they arrived from Mexico. Years later and El Faro still has the best burritos ever!
author: Rosie H.

description: The food here is always good! Love the burritos and quesadillas! El Farro is definitely a great place for some seriously good Mexican food. I dont come here often as I would like but I'll for sure keep coming back.
author: Alexis C.

description:
My husband and I have been going to El Farro in the Mission since we were teenagers, over 20 years.  Since we don't live close to them, and have to drive a bit to get there, we considered them a special treat.  We decided yesterday was going to be the day.  We drive across the city to pick up dinner only to be greeted with the worst experience ever, anywhere.

We order the usual super burrito for our son and two Mexican sandwiches for ourselves.  The woman making the food was someone we'd never seen before and was the only person behind the counter making food.  The only other person there was a man running the register who said he was the Manager.  She didn't know how to make the food we've been buying for years.  The burrito was rolled very loose and the sandwiches were not made according to their usual standards.  Mind you, we hadn't bought them yet.  We saw this by watching her make the food through the glass.

She didn't understand what we were asking her to do, like not put our lettuce on the hot grill to prevent wilting, or to make one spicy and the other not.  So we spoke to the "Manager", or attempted to anyway.  He ignored us, wouldn't acknowledge we were talking to him, until my husband got loud.  Then he proceeds to say "it's just a sandwich".  We argued that because we're customers paying for "just a sandwich", it should be made the way we want it, the way it's always been made in the past, citing hot lettuce as an example.  His response... "lots of people do it that way".   I was absolutely stunned that he didn't care the food wasn't being made according to their usual standards, or that the customer is saying it isn't right.  He absolutely did not care, stood there shrugging his shoulders and again said "geez, it's just a sandwich, don't have a heart attack over it".  

My response... I'm having a "heart attack" because you act like you don't care and that makes you look like an a@#hole that doesn't care about your customers.  He agreed he didn't.  with that said, we vowed to never return and made sure he knew he was loosing good, long time customers.  We'll never go back.  

The food is good, don't get me wrong.  But I can't spend my hard earned money in a business that could care less about the customer, and be so open with it.  He thought the food was fine, didn't care that the burrito would fall apart, or that the lettuce was served hot in a sandwich.  In his opinion it was fine and that's all there was to it.

It may be "just a sandwich", but it's that sandwich, and that burrito, and that taco that pays your bills buddy.  No customers, no money.  No money, no business.  It's simple.  Take care of your customers, especially those who've been with you for more than 20 years.  They don't deserve to be in business treating people that way.
author: Bobbie T.

description:
Good place for a quick and easy meal. Service is good. It had a neighborhood feel to it. No tourists here. Plenty of seating at any given time, but good for take out too. Credit card charges for $5 and above. Large bottled drink selection from the fridge.

Papusas were not great, but it's super fast and cheap because it's ready-made. They have both cheese and pork with cheese. Each one is a pretty filling size. The super burrito was okay, but really mushy with the refried beans. There wasn't much meat. Would be good for someone who just got their teeth worked on at the dentist. The enchiladas are also okay, but these are on the small side. Horchata was good.

Overall, food is okay, but service is good.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I love el faro usually.. At least the one in el camino. The service at this one sucks. Told the lady that the horchata taste watered down and she was arguing  with me that it tasted fine. Bitch go down a few blocks ans taste the horchata on mission. This place sucks and ill be never be going back here.
author: Vernon B.

description: Really greasy gross food. Also tried to charge me .25 for a napkin. I guess those are their "new" Mission prices. Walk a few blocks to 25th &  Mission, La Taqueria is far superior
author: Coco F.

description:
As others have said, not the best burrito in the neighborhood, but a pretty solid Mexican joint. I'd argue they have one of the best quesadillas in the Mission, so get one of those. Otherwise, the staff is nice and will explain stuff to you happily. They have a good selection of drinks in the back.

Also, the mexican breakfast is surprisingly good and way easier/cheaper than other more crowded spots (like San Jalisco) on weekend.

Only actual complaint is the 7pm close time -- so many times I would've rather came here, but ended up at Metate because Faro was closed. Stay open till 9 or 10!
author: Wilson L.

description:
I work across the street from El Faro and all my co-worker warned me that this place was not that good.  Today I forgot my lunch and had a short break, so I thought I'd give it a shot and see for myself.

I think this will be my last visit to El Faro.  The food is bland.  The food tastes like nothing.  I got the carnitas which should have had a ton of flavor.  Even the jalapenos were bland and without any heat.  I'm not sure how they can call the green water, guacamole.  I don't think there was any avocados in it.  Come on...this is California. 

It would be understandable if it was cheap, but it's the same price as all the other nearby taquerias.
author: Scott B.

description: We got bean n cheese burritos, which were pretty decent. Unfortunately their horchata tastes horrible, not sure if its just today's batch, but it tastes like dirty tap water.
author: Tianni Y.

description: This place is a block away from me and I've only been once in 7 years. Once was enough--no reason to settle for a mediocre taqueria in this neighborhood. El Metate, Cancun, even El Tonayense taco trucks are way better mission-stye burritos and tacos.
author: David G.

description:
With so many options available El Faro might not seem like anyone's first choice, but when combining super saver deals like ScoutMob then El Faro jumps to the top of my list.

The service was friendly and quick.  No one was in line before me which was a bit concerning but I had missed the lunch rush by about an hour.  The decor inside wasn't anything special.  One large buffet type counter with menu above and staff waiting patiently for you to either place your order or learn Spanish.  The choices are limited but with the addition of black beans and grilled chicken I was a happy camper for the moment.  My burrito was wrapped to go and upon unveiling of my post lunch time meal my dry burrito was pretty wet.  As Ruggy J. mentions, the condensation from the heated tortilla and tinfoil caused a soggy mess making it difficult to eat.  Not to mention the inside being a bit too juicy for my comfort.  When paying for a "Super" burrito I would expect something grand, yet I was able to finish mine to completion in a matter of minutes. No sir I wasn't a pig this day.

As noted above - my special deal was the reason for the visit and when only paying $3+ for a drink and burrito I can't complain too much.  2.5 stars for this Lighthouse.
author: Kevin J.

description: Best shrimp fajita tacos ever. I eat here at least a dozen times a year. The burritos are great as well, parking is always available right in front and there's always a table if you are looking to stay and eat.
author: Demi W.

description: Regular burrito with chicken, refried beans and rice (no salsa). Burrito is fresh, but bland. I don't eat raw onions, thus why I opted for no salsa fresca, but this burrito needs "something".
author: Angela E.

description: I love this place, we live an hour north and every time my dad would go to cash carry he would drive all the way el faro on Folsom. I was about 5 or 6 the first time now 40. My dad has past away so every time I stop here and eat it takes me right back to being with my dad. It still taste the same!! I'm glad it's still around and look forward to next time again with my son.
author: Nate H.

description: I have been going to El Faro's for many years. In the early 70s I would drive from Orange County to bring back a few super burritos to my follow Marines. That being said, today's El Faro's is a bit of a disappointment. Still a great burrito but not the outstanding burrito it once was. Did they invent the San Francisco? I don't know but now El Faro's super burrito is now just a good place to go.  Is that why there are no longer a few stores open? Please bring back the quality they had when the big guy was there  I truly miss that great big super chicken of the past... I would rate it at 3 stars but the memories of the best burrito in the world give it a extra star. The burrito of my home the Mission no longer shines as much as it did. Tomorrow, Toto's Pizza a main stay of the Mission till the fire in 1969 now only south of the city but still has great pizza, review tomorrow.
author: Howard D.

description: Don't come here looking for tacos. I had two tacos one asada one carnitas. Both terrible.
author: Lauren R.

description: The food is ok if you are in a hurry and in need of a quick bite. I always get the carne asada baby burrito $5.50 it plain but does the trick when you are hungry. My mom told me she seen the cook outside the store picking his nose, hope he went back and washed his hands.
author: Fred R.

description:
Good place for a quick, cheap taco.

Nothing special but probably the best Mexican food in that area.

They have a serve yourself salsa bar with a number of choices ranging from mild to spicy.  Nice touch.

Also, platters come with tortilla chips.
author: Brian K.

description:
I've been coming here for well over 10 years and their quality is still the best, their burritos are still huge, and they still have that same Mission ambiance I grew up with that I love so dearly.

They are the only place that makes real Acapulco burritos  ($8.99 with prawns, rice, crab salad spread, red and green bell peppers). The smaller "Farolito" taquerias make their own version of them but they are not the original. I also can't leave without having horchata (rice milk drink with fresh ground cinammon, vanilla, splash of lime) - it has been one of my favorite drinks in the world since I was little. Ahhh, I'm getting nostalgic!

Other things to note: 
- Their super burritos include ingredients that other places charge extra for, like sour cream and guacamole
- Their churros are soft on the inside, a bit crispy on the outside, and coated in just enough sugar (but not too much)
- There is always available street parking so you don't need quarters for the meter. 
- They always give you free chips and salsa

I haven't had a plate here, but honestly, I can't resist getting anything but a carne asada super burrito or an Acapulco burrito because it's what they do best.

I came in today and I noticed they recently moved the soda machines to behind the counter in order to create more seating space. Win!

Tip: Credit card requires a minimum $5 charge.
author: Mariela D.

description: Great spicy burrito. But the best part is that is extremely clean unlike other taquerias in mission. Very clean tables and bathroom. Will return for sure.
author: S K.

description:
What's with the burritos STILL being so eFFing soupy? Hasn't management seen the reviews? They all say the same thing, read up people. 
 
They are SOUPY & SKIMPING on the MEAT.  Fix it!  This location has been open long enough that "growing pains" aren't an excuse anymore. 

ALTERNATIVE: Go to Zona Rosa. They are less than one block down towards the park, on the corner of Shrader  & Hiaght Streets.  Eat there with the locals instead.
author: B K.

description:
Having eaten at this location for the past 35 years, I can say I have noticed a marked changed in the burritos. Back in the early 80's...they assembled the burritos differently...they used to spread the sourcream, gaucamole and cheese on the tortilla skin and then add beans, rice and meat. Now it's all mixed togather so the taste is not as even as it was before. 

The meat portions are much smaller than before too. Now the burrito is mostly beans and rice. Back then, the Super burritos were a lot cheaper (and you got more meat)...but still...at least put some meat into those "little burro's" or call it something else.

So Yes...I have tasted better...at this location some location35-25 years ago.
author: Working M.

description:
My husband and I are openly obsessed with their chorizo (or super with ham and bacon for the husband) breakfast burritos.  I am not sure what kind of magic is put into these, but it's what brings me back every time.

I add refried beans to mine (YUM) and he goes for double rice no beans.  The sauce that goes over the whole thing is probably a big factor in the magic. 

Definitely recommend this place.  They serve breakfast burritos all day which is especially great for weekend sleep in days.

Now I'm hungry just thinking about these.
author: Autumn B.

description: This place makes good burritos.  The super burrito with steak is pretty good.  It comes with salsa and some chips. Service is fast and efficient.  Their pupusa is good. The Horchata is good.  They accepted my Scout Mob coupon.  They have standard menu of burritos with choice of meats,   nachos, tacos, sandwiches, horchata, and pupusas. They accepted my Scout Mob coupon.  I would come to this place again.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Nice selection at this Mexican place. I was able to select healthier options for my chicken burrito - grilled chicken, black beans, and a whole wheat tortilla. The salsa was good, could be spicier but I'm a fan of the really spicy stuff. 

Staff was very friendly, which can be rare these days. They let me know about all the options when ordering. 

Not the cheapest burrito I've ever bought but it was pretty big - got two meals out of it. Didn't come with chips :(
author: Dena E.

description:
Confused workers and stale chips. No bueno.

Aside from that, the chicken tamales were pretty good, but it doesn't come with tamales sauce unless you order the entrée.

Chicken super burrito was indeed super.  It will fill the biggest of appetites.

There are better choices in the city, so I don't think I will be back any time soon.
author: Michelle S.

description:
My quest to find a quality burrito in San Francisco marches on....

I don't understand what the problem is. Burritos have to be the easiest comfort food item on the planet to whip together. Get some refried beans, some rice (but not too much), a meat item and a few peripheral additions... wrap that shits in a grilled (not steamed!) tortilla, and you've got a meal. 

But seriously, though... what the fuck? In a city filled with talented culinary professionals, why can't someone figure out how to make a decent burrito? I know that's a generalization, and there are places that *do* exist, which will likely put the brakes on my bitching and complaining... but failed attempt after failed attempt just has me so very aggravated.

On a scale of 1-10, El Faro would probably nab a 2 on the scale of tasty burritos in San Diego... but sadly, in San Francisco, this was the best burrito I've had yet. It was of the breakfast variety, and it had a very slight resemblance to what I was raised on. Eggs, bacon, refried beans, cheese and hot sauce. On paper, it should have been a knock out... but it was just OK at best. 

Something I seriously don't under stand is why every Mexican food joint in SF heats up their burritos with a panini press? From first hand experience, there isn't a goddamn food purveyor anywhere in Mexico that uses a contraption like that to heat up a tortilla, or the entire burrito for that matter. They use a flat grill or an open flame. 

And the wrapping... don't even get me started. When steaming a burrito in a press, it adds condensation to the tortilla. Then, when you wrap it in tin foil, it not only expedites the spread of wetness, it also locks in the moisture and causes the entire burrito to become a soggy, sloppy mess. Again, in Mexico and San Diego where the burrito has been perfected, there isn't a legitimate taco shop anywhere that double-wraps a steamed burrito in tin foil... it's always paper. Seems easy enough to fix, right? Well, apparently not in El Faro's case, or the case of many others in the city. 

El Farolito is my last hope. If what I've heard is to be believed, Christmas will be saved in the Ruggeford H. Joesten III household. But until then, I'll be waiting burrito-less with bated breath.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
I live close-by but avoided this place for months when I first moved in because of the poor Yelp reviews. 

I tried it a few times over the last few weeks. The burritos are soupy (as others note), but the portions are generous and the service is relatively fast. The flavor is okay.

Lettuce makes the burritos a little less mushy.
author: Max H.

description:
I've been eating El Faro since 1973, which means I've been eating it longer than most of you little young punks have been alive. 

Great burritos. Not the best but great and very consistent. 

You young people bitching about El Faro should go to Chipotle and get your gringo burritos. 

Ye ghods, I hate young people.
author: Pete B.

description: Over charge for my food! Food is tasteless and of poor quality! Disappointed will not be coming back. :(
author: Michelle F.

description:
Visited this Mission location to ease my Mexican food craving. It could be the SoCal-trained Mexican food palate but I get these cravings sometimes...

Pupusa - corn tortillas stuffed with pork and cheese are made-to-order and were delightfully enjoyed fresh off the oven; I think the trick is to have them when they are still hot.

Taqueria Burrito - grilled steak, monterey jack cheese, whole beans, and salsa fresca available on wheat tortilla (love that they have the option!); wholesome ingredients and not too big, but I wouldn't mind a little more flavors. 

Friendly service from the ladies behind the counter. They made each order with TLC, which was further evidenced by the locals and regulars.

Take-Away: A pleasant experience of no-nonsense homemade tastes for both my mouth and wallet. Thanks to Scout Mob, quenched the craving for ~$5.
author: Carol K.

description: Very rude, and you get what you pay for, the quality of the meat is poor, and they give you 6 to 7 chips, if you want great burritos and good quality meat GO TO LA TAQUERIA on 25th and mission, next to the italian desert place (DIANDA'S)  the best burritos, their doing something right if there's always a line, try it and you'd thank me......
author: Chipotle Me M.

description: Ridiculous prices for 'add-ons". If you want REAL avocado instead of the soup they call guacamole, you have to pay $1.00. For 1/4 of an avocado!!
author: Leslie C.

description:
The burritos are crap.  They don't even try to drain water off of the beans - they just slap that mess in with some gristly nasty cold meat and let you pick the grossness out of your mouth as you try to eat it.  Even with ScoutMob, I feel ripped off.  They aren't super friendly behind the counter and their prices are on the steep side.  Overall, a weeeeak performance in a region of the city famous for good burritos.  They should throw these guys out and open another El Burrito Express here.

Yuck!
author: Desmo K.

description: Props for lasting more than 50 years, but they don't seem to be trying too hard to last 50 more. They heated my chile verde meat up in the microwave before slopping it onto the tortilla. There are plenty of better places nearby.
author: Patrick S.

description: I've been coming to this El Faro for over 20 years and this is the first time that I dislike the food. I ordered 2 pollo asado burritos to go and the meat tasted very rubbery and it was completely tasteless. I don't know if the ownership has changed but the quality has gone down considerably. Save your money and appetite for some other Mexican place.
author: Sergio G.

description:
I have been eating these burritos for 35 years!  When we moved out of California to Atlanta; El Faro's is always on the top of our list when we come visit.

In fact we usually fly into San Francisco and our family has them waiting in the car for us at the airport.  

My Gringo Wife even fell in love with the place and she grew up on yuppie food!   Now   my kids love the place and have been eating them from shortly after birth.

When the family comes to visit us in Atlanta they swing by El Faro's with a insulated bag and fill in up with burritos to fly us out to Atlanta.

4 Super Chicken's Please! The staff is always very nice and the steamed tortilla is what makes El Faro's unique.

I don't usually take the time to write reviews, but I started to read some of these 1 star reviews and I would recommend for those people to stay at Chipotle (BTW is owned by McDonalds what do they know about burritos?)

If you can even keep a Chipotle burrito down after eating stay away from El Faro's because you would not be able to handle all the flavor and authenticity!
author: Michael K.

description:
Not terrible, not great, especially considering how many mexican places there are nearby.

Dreary lighting. Nothing special inside.
author: Kyle P.

description:
Fair.

Slab of choice was the Acapulco. Shrimp, salsa, grilled onions and peppers, sliced tomatoes, rice and a crab spread.

Wanted to avoid the mayo-based crab spread so they subbed black beans. Wheat tortillas available.

Ten bucks wasn't cheap. Fortunately Scoutmob offset half the cost. Decent amount of shrimp, friendly service and a quality final product secures them a third star.
author: Jason B.

description: I love this place!! Great food at a good price and everyone is polite. There service is quick they even remember my order. Overall happy and will continue coming here never had a bad meal.
author: Jasmin P.

description:
Ohh yes.  Oh yes.

You see, I just came from a place (Boston) where it's not a stretch to call Chipotle your favorite burrito.  Yes, really (hey, they're pretty good!)

So when we discovered El Faro (like, on day one), it was a no-brainer.  This place, allegedly having served the world's very first burrito back on some day in the '60s, is the real deal.  The guac is juicy and delish.  The meat is perfectly roasted.  The beans are heavenly.  The burritos are enormous, messy, and wrapped in foil (as it should be).  

Sorry Chipotle, you stick to suburbia, I'll stick to El Faro.
author: Jillian Y.

description: I have been coming here since I was a kid. The burritos are awesome (I always order a burrito) . Not being Latino I would not personally know how authentic it is but in the past when I brought Latino friends here they ordered the tacos and they tell me "they are just like mama's" one quick tip, try the Acapulco I never see anyone else order it except for when people see me eating it however everyone who tries it seems to like it (as long as you are into seafood)
author: Phil P.

description: My family and I have been coming to this specific El Faro for years. It's a great spot to get a quick, no-nonsense meal. I think they've perfected their steak and rice and they also make great "no meat" burritos. (The chopped steak soaks in juice so it's super tender and the rice is always light and fluffy.) It's fair to say I've seen them add a bit too much guac or sour cream to the center of a burrito, or not drain enough juice from the meat, but they are always responsive when I make requests and I can't remember a time I wasn't satisfied with my order. I will note that the chips were way better in the 90's, back when there was the parking lot with a giant mural across the street, just saying.
author: Zan T.

description: While visiting  the city i wanted to eat somewhere in which I used to eat as a kid.While I was going to my usual spot I drove by El Faro and I thought to myself why not!? I ended up ordering a carnitas burrito and I was disappointed. The carnitas was very watery and was lacking in flavor. Kudos for the big portions but to me that doesn't matter. Quality over quantity any day!
author: Richard G.

description:
This review of one star may be a bit harsh, considering I ate it all, and it was acceptable, which is normally good for two or three stars in my world.  But it is simply the worst taqueria I've been to in the Mission, and there's no reason to settle for it when there are so many MUCH better options within even two square blocks.  It's overpriced ($2 more than standard for the area, for a super burrito), it's tortillas are steamed, not grilled, they don't melt the cheese, they charge extra for random things without telling you, and the staff appears more surly than even the low bar for this kind of restaurant.  

If you're considering going here, look for a place with better ratings, or just keep walking down the block.

I was thinking of something positive to say, but they don't have a TV, they don't have good Agua Fresca, they don't have nice seating.........nope, I've got nothing.  Nothing at all that distinguishes them in a good way.
author: Zachary R.

description:
Good decent burrito!! 
Any place that has Vicente Fernandez's mariachi outfit on the wall better be legit!! This place delivers.
author: Daniel D.

description:
these days they have become overly 'pricy' and very much smaller portions.  Having tried many items on there menu. Taste..nothing special here, rather normal/plain tasting overall. The "Super" Burrito ive found is mostly filler (rice & beans) with a 'sprinkling' of your favorite meat (non vegi) they ladle some liquid/juice to make the buro juicy.

Did i mention...they charge extra for everything!!!! GOOD GRIEF!!! So if your busy watching how they build your order & you want extra anything, be prepared for ..."ThatsExtra!!"

...back in the day (over15yrs ago) their food used to taste awesome with large portions and cheap prices for the masses. Seems Capitalism leads the way here over great food at good prices. (Sad)

...would i recommend it? NO! 
There are handfuls of great authentic Mexican food places smattering the Inner Mission, better food & portions to treat your pallet and without 'price shock' after especially if your a good sized man wanting to get full!!
author: Bruce G.

description: I have been coming here with my family since I moved to California 20+ years ago.  Very rarely do I leave unsatisfied. Pretty much set up like your standard burrito shop, but the flavor of the burrito is amazing. I have been able to share this restaurant with many friends, all of which have enjoyed it. Highly recommend giving it a shot. You will not be disappointed.
author: Andy B.

description: Employee satisfaction here must be low. At all 3 El Faro's I've been to, I've never been able to cop up one smile, not even from the grandma lady working there tonight. Instead, it is a look of gloom whenever I order my food. And gloom it is. I walked in, tried to order 1 taco, beans and rice. It was about $7 without chips or salsa, or much of anything for that matter. I looked at the somewhat soggy tortilla waiting to be filled, and I said, "cancel that, I'm going to (2 star) Taco Bell."  Yeah, it's gotten that bad here. Please, close this God forsaken place and let some fresh new talent move in. Everyone will be happier, especially the employees.
author: Brian J.

description: It was only okay because I was really hungry. It wasn't too bad but I just didn't like how  mushy and liquidy the super carnitas burrito was.
author: Allyson L.

description:
i had the weirdest enchilada in the history of mankind today. it tasted sweet with cinnamon sugar flavor in the red sauce. i told the staff and they said, "i know."
why would i want a sugary enchilada. did i wake up and end up in the bizzaro SF?
i ordered a carne asada and a carnitas expecting savory flavorful tastiness. i get sugary cinnamon sugar!
i must be losing my mind, 
never again will i even think of ordering this menu item here.
even after smothering the dish in salsa i could not get rid of the sweet flavor.
ugh.
skip this.
author: Jeff W.

description: I am a sf mission native went too school next door . El faro was my favorite for years about 10 years ago it went downhill meats and guac and chips all changed for the worst . I try it every few years to see if its changed.  No luck yet.But luckily theres two that have kept the old recipes and ill travel down to get a childhood meal that taste deadon. THE OTHER ELFAROS IN THE CITY ARE HIT OR MISS THE BEST ONE IN THE CITY IS broadway  so the best two are el faro on el camino or elsuper burrito on el camino in milbrae. Tryem. Youll see
author: Chris C.

description: Pretty standard taqueria.  Nothing worth returning for.
author: Michael E.

description:
I'm saddly disappointed.  This used to be my #1 taqueria in SF (for a long time) when I was a kid.  I still remember when my mom used to stop by here on her way home for work and bring home a super burrito.  It was the delicious.  They had the best carne asada meat.  When I was old enough to drive, me and my cousins used to go her all the time to get a super burrito.

I went there not too long ago and was very excited to bite into an El Faro super burrito since I haven't had one for years, but soon did I realize it wasn't the same.  For a minute there, I thought I was in the wrong taqueria.  The burrito was below average.  It felt like someone just took away a part of my childhood.  I spoke to the cashier briefly and discovered that the the present owners aren't the same from the years past.  

Hmmmm, that's too bad.  Bring back the old El Faro...please.
author: Ricky M.

description:
I come all the way from South San Francisco to go here for burritos... which is not a big deal, since it's the BEST tasting burrito I have ever had in the whole Bay Area.

I have gone to other Taqueria's, such as El Farolito, La Tapatia, La Morena, La Cumbre, La Perla & Celia's, but none of them have made my burrito craving totally satisfied like El Faro's does.  Their rice, beans and meat have so much flavor.  We still go to other places, but when my wife and I want a really good burrito, we come here!!!
author: Richard F.

description: Get a spicy el pollo fajita w coconut bread!
author: Aristides N.

description:
Even though this is our (boyfriend and I's) yelp account...I am writing the review on El Faros.

EL FAROS is the best, and will always be the best burrito place to me. I have been coming here since I was a baby and my father grew up with the owner, so we have had a wonderful relationship with the restaurant.

However, they did get new owners and with this brought slight changes. All the ingredients for the burritos are the same, thankgoodness! But, they do not make their own chips anymore, they buy them now which upsets me. 

They also have managed to put the smallest little convenience store section at the cash register which is kind of odd, but since I love the food so much I turn blind to it. So besides the chips and the odd register section,

The food
the staff
the cheap cheap prices
is my kind of thing!
author: EJ G.

description:
What i like about this place is that opens early.  Food is ok.  Good for the price (cheap).  I tried the veggie burrito and a bean and cheese burrito.  That's what i usually get there.  They weren't fantastic, but they were ok.  

A cheap place to eat.  Nice staff.  Some people like this place more than El Farolito at 24th and Mission, but I strongly disagree.  

Anyways, El Faro is good place to grab a burrito in the AM.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
MMM This place is good, definitely different from San Jose burritos but good nonetheless. 

It's a more watery type burrito, so the juices will be dripping down your hands as you eat it. It could use a dash of heat and a hint of lime and that would be perfect.

The regular burrito has rice and the taqueria has cheese. I chose the taqueria cause I loveeeeeerssss cheese. 

We came here mostly cause there was a ScoutMob on this place (50%) order made our 2 burritos equal the price of one, good deal. 

IDK if I would come back though because I'm not huge on juicy burritos and I would like to have cheese AND rice in my burrito. BUT overall, the food was good, and even better the next day when microwaved for a minute and consumed with a fork and knife, YUM.
author: Jenny A.

description: As I'm eating this, all I can think is how smooth this carne asada burrito was. I think I would've been better off with a bean and cheese burrito. It's quite long and good sized. The few small pieces of what made it a carne asada burrito actually took away from the burrito itself. I couldn't really taste the carne asada. The beans, rice, sour cream, and guac just fit all together. The salsa tasted more like store bought. The chips were a little stale.Overall, a good sized burrito, tasty for "vegetarians".
author: Arnold W.

description:
As my roommate most astutely pointed out, this place stays open for one reason: the high school next door.  Fourteen year olds hopped up on 4Loko too broke/drunk to care if their $5 burrito tastes like it was microwaved 1 hour ago.
I've been here twice.  It's across the street, literally.  The first time I had an al pastor burrito.  It was cold, made poorly, and the taste was far below average.  I then decided to give El Faro one more chance.  Got pupusas.  They were terrible.  Nowhere near fresh, clearly micorwaved, dry on the inside, soggy on the outside, and tasting vaguely of foam rubber.  Even the curtido (Latin slaw) couldn't save the pupusa, mostly because it too sucked.   
El Faro, you suck.  You are a waste of a prime corner location.  And you better hope that high school next door doesn't close.  Or that they outlaw 4Loko.
author: Eric S.

description: By fare my favorite super burrito's Ive ever had period! And I have had allot of burrito's (my favorite food). I will kill for one of these burrito's! Ask for extra gravy! it's what makes their burrito's! Biggest problem is that they are not open late. This place is also considered one of the first places to serve a super burrito in SF!
author: Brandon W.

description:
This is my go-to Taquería; I'm still eating here at least once a week. If anything the food is getting better and better. The service is so friendly

Nothing cures a hangover like their super breakfast burrito.

Literally everything is good here and over the years I'm pretty sure I've tried everything. This weekend I ordered a grilled chicken super burrito with a little bacon and it was amazingly good.

****5/24/08*****

I eat here a couple times a week so I guess I like it. It went under new management about a year ago and the food quality has improved greatly. The boss is a nice lady and the women that work there are as sweet as sugar. Try ordering in Spanish if you can, they'll get a kick out of it.
author: Manny F.

description: It's always been my assumption that it's pretty hard to really screw up basic Italian or Mexican food. Well, kudos to El Faro for managing the task. The burrito was utterly flavorless, the meat full of gristle, and the tortilla chips tasted like Fritos.
author: Jojo S.

description: I agree with Dean C that this is one of the better Carnitas burritos in the Mission, although it is not always consistent. I got one the other day and I thought it was the best burrito in the Mission (along w my bf) then I got one yesterday, and it was pretty soggy.  I get the super burrito without guacamole. It is huge (hard to finish one myself, but I'm wanting more when I try to split it). Never a long line like other burrito shops, and prettty easy to park. Better than El Farolito and better than Taqueria Cancun, although Taqueria Cancun beats it late night bc it stays open after the bars, while El Faro closes pretty early. Get it with the refried beans. I'll have to try that Prawn burrito others are talking about. They also have the Coke in the bottle.
author: Jessica S.

description: El Faro is not bad but decent at best, especially when you are surrounded by plenty of other fine tacquerias in the Mission. I got the big burrito with al pastor. The meat tasted good and tender but lacked the punch and richness that you would find at El Farolito. The rest of the accompanying items like refried beans, lettuce, etc. just tasted bland and did not really add to the burrito. This is a quick stop to get fast Mex but Faro is half the experience of Farolito.
author: Ed L.

description: Too bad we can't give out "0" stars.  This place has ripped off the public for too long.  Worst 'mexican' food served since Santana served his troops at the Alamo.  They must own the bldg. because there's no way you could pay rent servng that slop.
author: Peter F.

description: I love El Faro: their old school "Mexican fast foods" sign complete with beaming lighthouse, their clientele that is equal parts neighborhood hipsters and neighborhood families, their burritos.  I of course stick to the vegetarian side of things, sometimes going for the very basic rice/beans/cheese and other times adding extras like guac and sour cream.  Ingredients are always generously portioned, and your food is made to order right there in front of you.  Authentic food at a great price.
author: Heidi D.

description:
Let me start by saying this review only applies to their breakfast burritos way too early on Saturday mornings. This is my absolute go to spot for hangover food after a restless night of sleeping from a little too much fun on a Friday night. 

Now I'm giving them 3 stars because I don't personally think they're the best breakfast burritos in the world, at least not for my taste. But my husband thinks they're amazing. They come with eggs, cheese, salsa, meat (he loves the chorizo), and beans. I personally think the eggs are always overcooked and the proportions just aren't right. However, they are somewhat magical to me because without fail within an hour or two of consuming one of these, I always feel so much better!

The woman who's always there when I go in is awesome. She always has a cheerful smile for me when I come stumbling in, holding my head in pain. If you live in the neighborhood, like I do, I would check it out.
author: Foodie K.

description:
^^^ ^^^ I like the vibe here.^^^ ^^^^
The tile mural is one of the best art pieces I have seen in SF. It has a lovely 1970's glow. The place feels like family. Everyone I met working there was really sweet.

As a vegetarian, I question there beans and the possibility of lard. I just could not tell and I was scared to ask. Also beware of high school hours ie. lunch and 3pm; there was a flood of awkward teenagers.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
This place is around the corner from where I work so I go there fairly frequently. I don't think I've had anything other than the Burritos, so bear that in mind. That said the Burrito's are pretty darn good. I'm still not entirely sure about steaming the tortillas. To me to the tortilla should be heated up on the grill. Regardless, they are good. I usually get the carne asada super burrito with the "spicy" salsa. It's a good medium heat. The burritos are to big for me to finish in a single sitting, and that's A-OK with me. 

If you've got a craving for a burrito the size of your head and are in the Mission this is a pretty good place to go.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I'm pretty mission-oriented when it comes to eating Mexican Food. I will go to one particular place because they have ONE particularly good item. Everything else is just a waste of ink or crusty restaurant lighting--I don't even bother with asking.

El Faro (San Francisco) has THE best Carnitas Super Burrito. Go with the Pinto beans, guacamole if you like that muck (not for me), and get the hotter salsa with some of the regular salsa. This burrito smacks the others around with a heavy hand (they are heavy with the Carnitas.)

El Farolito, ehhh...
La Morena, OHH-VERR-RAY-TED
Every other burrito place (often imitating, never duplicating)

The secret is the sauce they put in after they've loaded everything else.

I give this place a 4 stars because there is no refill on the Horchata. God, that Horchata is good, I need a swimming pool of that stuff. But the good part is, they have glass-bottled Mexican Coke. Strangely it shouldn't, but it does KICK the ASS off American coke. Glass bottle, real sugar, all the stuff soda used to be. It's catching on again (finally), even my local 7-11 in Daly City carries the stuff.

Better have sharp eyes if you need to use the restroom, there is nothing lit back there! Parking is a tad harder because of the new complex where the old parking lot used to be. If you happen to be disappointed in the food, it's probably because you didn't follow my directions on what to order. Serves you right.
author: Dean C.

description:
Eek! I don't understand what happened when I went here. With all these good reviews, it would seem that my experience was an anomaly, but I repeat, EEK!!! My first thought upon biting into the burrito was "Oh...that tortilla is not quite right..." It was soggy like they had put it in the steamer three times longer than it should have been. I realized that the cheese was cold. They had put the cheese on after steaming the burrito so it didn't melt. It just sort of sat there on top of some meat that looked and tasted like it had been left on hot plates just a bit too long. The quac had no texture to it, and I couldn't even taste the "spicy" salsa. 

I wouldn't even bother reviewing this except that the boy got a sandwich that he claimed to really enjoy (though it was lacking in the mayo department in his opinion.) 

Maybe I'll give this place another shot due to all of the good reviews below, but when there are so many other good taquerias around, why bother?
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Having a Latin partner makes going to a taqueria about as redundant as a Bobby Flay burger.  The more authentic stuff is always cooked at home but sometimes its nice to get a burrito with no muss no fuss.  I'm pretty particular about my burritos and almost order the same type every time.  Carn Asada with extra cilantro, a mix of re-fried and black beans, with all the extras (guac, sour cream, etc..) in a green tortilla when available.   I also like a lime wedge or two on the side for an occasional squeeze.  I have a favorite place for this and I am still looking for somewhere locally to match the taste of my favorite.  Twenty miles is a bit far to go for a burrito but I will usually pick one up, hungry or not, when I go through town.
El Faro's isn't a winner but still one damn good burrito.  The filling is moist even saucy and that's the way I like them.  Can't stand a dry burrito.  Staff was accomidating and friendly.  Thanks to Scout Mob again for luring us to another good eats.
author: John W.

description:
The cleanliness wasn't an issue for me; everything looked in order.
However, the best they could do as a vegetarian was the "no meat burrito."  This was underwhelming, even in light of being a little drunk at 5:30 on a Monday evening.  Give me some grilled veggies for Mama's sake!
author: Nathan M.

description:
YOU GOT TO TRY THE ACALPULCO BURRITO! 
Grilled prawns, bell peppers, onions, with crab spread. Honestly the best burrito I have ever had!

I was introduced to this amazing creation by my boss. He used to work for that company and said that was his favorite burrito. So I gave it a try, and boy was he right!!! I brought some home after work to bring to my parents to try. They both loved it! It's a pretty big burrito too. I was only able to eat half and saved the other half for lunch the next day. It's an $8 burrito, but it was well worth it!

They have party platters too! My company orders here for lunch sometimes also! Taco Bar baby!!
author: Steph C.

description:
Crappy food!

25 years ago, this place was the shit!  They were the only game in town, now - they need to sell this place to some affluent couple so they could revamp the location (since this is the norm in The Mission District, nowadays).  Maybe a internet cafe - because we don't have enough of them in the city!
author: Emmy d.

description:
Ok, so this is my 1st official yelp review. I've thought of yelping for years now, but haven't gotten around to doing it. I guess it's time for you folks to hear me out now.

I hate to start off on the negative side, but I have to keep it real. I've read most of the    Reviews of people who say they have been coming to place the last 40 yrs or so. I agree with some saying it was the worlds greatest carne asada burrito. Something about that flavored meat, the tasty rice, melted cheese and all that good stuff. As a child I went to George Moscone elementary k-5 right next door which is now John Oconnel High. the schools switched sometime long ago Fr Harrison st. Anyways I went back about a month ago, 25 yrs or so longing for the great carne asada taste. Pretty weird feeling after all these yrs the place looked the same. I was actually looking to see if this old heavy set guy who always sat on a stool was still there. Sure enough he was seating in the back on a regular chair with a walker. The  guy looks the same, I asked about the other heavy set guy who owned the place, The guy passed away about 10 yrs ago. Burritos were watery no flavor, just not the same. Nothing last forever. The bakery across the street gone, Jerry's tattoo shop, and the old Mi Rancho supermarket gone. Sorry El Faro , but it's not the same. 

For you other folks if you like the food that's good for you, but if your from the old days you know what I'm talking about.
author: Oliver M.

description:
I'm sorry, but default beans are NOT refried. If I order a burrito and don't specify anything, you should be putting pinto beans in there. This was especially annoying since I got my burrito without rice, meaning what I essentially got was tortilla soup wrapped up in a tortilla. I was starving, so I actually managed to eat some of this, but I used a spoon like this was a savory mexican ice cream cone.

On a positive note, I've had a quesadilla here and it was pretty good. Only think stopping it from getting a single star.

I hate the "no free chips with entrees" and the no salsa on the side.
author: Jennie H.

description:
I've been coming to this place since I was a fetus and I'm hoping that they have an El Faro in heaven too because this place is awesome =)

To me and mi familia, nothing beats an old school El Faro burrito... They're massive and filled with flavor. I like to complement my pollo super  burrito with some chocolate milk... mmmm. The burritos are so juicy that you have to be careful not to leave any burrito evidence on your clothes. 

The restaurant itself has looked the same all of my life and i truly appreciate its consistency! So it's not fancy and maybe it doesn't cater to demanding non-Latino sensibilities, but it leaves some charm in between all of the mission's renovated buildings. Eat in your car if the orange and brown colors are that bothersome... the point is, just eat one of their awesome burritos!

and yeah... the pupusas are pupusarific! The Latino Day parade is coming up and I can't wait for my El Faro visit!
author: Michelle B.

description:
my workmates had to wake me up after i had their chorizo breakfast burrito . . . and that's a good thing when it comes to a Taqueria review, imo. you may disagree, but the size and yummie content were astounding.

i've eaten here a few times, but that's the only thing i've gotten. the breakfast death burrito. nom nom nom
author: Andrew C.

description:
This is my debut review - so for me, nothing else is more deserving than El Faro on 20th and Folsom (The other EF locations just don't seem to have the same effect on me).  Aside from steamed rice...Mexican food just happens to be my favorite food...and I have been a deep fan of this place since the age of 5.  

I've been living far far away from El Faro and city for a while now...and its not uncommon for me to take that 45 mile trek just for a Super Carnitas  Burrito!  - nuf said.
author: Derik P.

description:
Biggest burrito in SF.  Dunno if that is true or not but it sure seemed like it.  

Thumbs UP: Delicious Carnitas 
Thumbs DOWN:  Questionable store front hygine practices.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I just finished half a burrito from El Faro not too long ago.  The sucker was huge, but not mouth watering delicious.  I enjoy black beans in my burritos so I was sad when I realized the restaurant only served runny refried beans.  Add that with their runny guac, and the whole burrito ends up being a liquid mess.  They gave me a stack of napkins, but it wasn't enough to keep myself clean.  

The staff was really nice though, and that alone gets an extra star because customer service is such a rarity these days.  Otherwise a 3.
author: Denise I.

description:
Sunday morning I was craving some Mexican breakfast and decided to give El Faro a try.  I don't know who told these guys that there should be refried beans in a breakfast burrito...but I'd like to give them a big wet sloppy kiss.  

2 eggs + diced ham + refried beans + hot sauce + jalapenos + giant tortilla = heaven. 

Also, the service was fast and friendly and its really clean in there.

I'll be back soon to see if lunch and dinner are as yummy!"
author: Miss Information X.

description: Forgot to mention that after years of being accosted and practically strip-searched by Immigration after flying back into the country, my grandma always enjoyed getting burritos from here as a consolation prize. They're certainly in their own category of burritos. But if it can cheer my grandma up after being detained, questioned, and prodded for simply being awesome, it should make you happy too.
author: Loli L.

description: Great burritos had a shrimp one it was great.  A special sauce and really tasty..  My husband did take out so I am not sure how the restaurarant was but the food was good.
author: Grace M.

description: Me and My Family won't be going there again after11/19/11. Tried to charge 2.50 for extra meat,Are u Serious?  At the same time burritos look like long ass corn rolls not "Home of the Super Burritos". (Please!)
author: Bernadette F.

description: The definitive bad SF burrito, ever the same since the beginning of time.  Who cares if it's as big as my head (actually bigger)?  Personally, I'd rather have two La Taqueria burritos in my system than one of these disgusting rice bombs.  Strictly for those who prefer size over substance.
author: Teal H.

description: Every time I am in San Fran to visit family, el faro is a must.  They seem a little different since management has changed (different hot peppers, more watery?), all in all still a great burrito.
author: C S.

description: So I went to El Faro and I ordered the Gigantic Burrito. The lady asked me if I wanted everything on it and I said yes. When she came back she gave me the biggest burrito I've ever seen, so big the woman standing next to me said "That's quite a big burrito you have there". All I said in response was " Why yes it is"  :)
author: Angel R.

description: That's some good pupusa right there, yes indeed. The fifteen zits I will have tomorrow as a result will be worth it.
author: Alyssa R.

description: No not good at all. And I don't even remember what I've eaten but it absolutely sucks. Period. No zero stars on here huh?
author: Gina R.

description: I've been here a few times in my life, and about ten years ago (when I was five), I remember eating their burritos, and liking them. Quite frankly, now, the burritos are sub-par, the wettest burritos I have EVER eaten. They only use refried beans, sour cream, cheese (mozzarella, I think), jalapenos, a bit of hot sauce, rice (no salsa), extremely watered down guacamole, and the meat they use is loaded with liquid in itself. When I eat the burrito, I literally have to slurp the contents to eat it. Also, they steam the tortillas, which I found kind of absurd, making the burrito somewhat flimsy, requiring the tin foil to support it. The burritos are really small for a "super burrito" and costs $8.34 for something that's not super filling. Though the texture of the burrito isn't great, the flavors actually do make up for it. The only thing in the burrito that has a decent non-liquidy texture are the jalapenos. Still, what tipped me off, for this terrible review of their restaurant, was the service. There were three or four employees inside. It was around 6:40 pm, and the sign posted said that they closed at 7. So I knocked on their door to get their attention that I was a customer and wanted food. The old guy (I think was the boss) stares at me, and just ignores me. Then, the three female employees looked up at me, and also ignored me, making clear that they saw me. I pounded on the door, at least waiting to at least speak to them, or hint that they were closed. But no, they just ignored me, doing their thing. I thought they would at least be courteous enough to at least speak/gesture to me. What ticked me off, was their lack of respect for their customers--I truly felt like just flipping them off for their rudeness. Next time, I'm going on Mission St. to find a place with manners and better food.
author: Steven Z.

description: I passed this place by accident and went inside  because there used to be a great burrito place on Mission and 1st Street with the same name so I thought this place might be affiliated.  I got the super carne asada burrito for $7 plus tax.  The size was ridiculously small and the taste was just okay.  I guess they cut down the size to make up for the slow business.
author: Edmund W.

description: Possibly the originators of the San Francisco burrito! Fantastic food and atmosphere. Also try the place on El Camino in South San Francisco. The owner once said that the drug trade was the initial funding to start El Faro. I've been coming here since the early 80's. Authentico!
author: The C.

description: The only thing I've had here is the burritos, but they are so money I can't pass up the opportunity to eat one in favor of ordering something else.  The super spicy salsa is what makes this place stand out.  Of course, I'm always a fan of a taqueria that has wheat, tomato and spinach tortilla options as well.  Super friendly staff too.  AND they have the Snapple from the Celebrity Apprentice, which I've been unable to find anywhere else.  Whoop!
author: Amy C.

description: I grew up in the Mission District and used to go to El Faro on a regular basis for fast and tasty Mexican food.  Luv their breakfast burritos.  Cheap eats!!!
author: Raider J.

description:
it is what it is. huge burrito (atomic bowel death log) for a cheap price. it is not some silly fusion/ organic/ no animals where harmed in the production of this meal.  it is a taqueria, plain and simple. it may not have the latest trendy fusion combo. this is a good ol' fashioned meat, cheese, beans, rice, guacamole type of place. you go in, order, eat and go into a food coma. 

that is all i am looking for in a burrito. quick, meaty, filling, and tasty.
author: Mr. Rivet ..

description: El Faro is my go-to lunch spot; I've been coming here at least once a week for nearly 8 months. Their aguas frescas selection is lacking (hope you like horchata!) but the ladies behind the counter can slap together a mean burrito. You won't find anything out of the ordinary here, just consistently good taqueria dishes. I personally recommend the chicken fajita burrito  and carne asada tacos (get 'em spicy).
author: Branden R.

description: I don't know why it's taken me so long to write a review on this place, I've been coming here for over a year and almost always make a weekly habit of getting their quesidilla on wheat (love that it's an option!).  Food is consistently good.  Uber cheap (big fat veggie burrito only costs $4.50!) and service is typically friendly.  If you get to know Teresa (she's usually at the register) she will hook you up with free extra salsa to the standard one that they provide, otherwise it's $0.50 for every additional one you ask for.  If you have to pay the extra change, it's really good and worth it.  Anyways, El Faro's great and I give it a big fat yaaaay!
author: Swetha G.

description: Note:  This location does not have black beans, but they do have the yummy green salsa that the other locations have.  I have to agree with Jeff -- it's kinda grungy.  Very busy at lunchtime!
author: Andi T.

description: 5 stars for the El Faro burritos that live on in my memory.  Gloppy beans, under seasoned rice, fake guacamole and they skimp on the meat...but by golly, those puppies are HUGE.  I'll agree that these aren't the best in the city, but perhaps it's an acquired taste.  Also...they've got pupusas!  I love me some pupusas...and while they aren't freshly made (they've got to nuke them), they are still tasty!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Damned good muchaca breakfast burrito. Not quite as good as some of the stuff I had in San Diego last weekend, but still damned good.
author: Josh O.

description: Below average. I went in looking for a tasty burrito and left still looking for a tasty burrito. Very plain burrito with lots of rice. Got a carne asada special but maybe got a teaspoon of watery guac and sour cream. Several better options in the area.
author: Chris B.

description: Here's the scoop - or at least this was the case when I lived less than a block away - the nachos kick butt! I used to get the regular nachos on almost a weekly basis. Everything else I tried was mediocre at best. Burritos often were lukewarm and unexciting. They don't serve beer, which was not such an issue since I was usually taking my food back to my place to enjoy, but be aware. If you're not in the mood for nachos, go elsewhere (i.e., Los Jarritos)
author: Amy K.

description: I just really love these burritos. I moved away but these are still in my top 5 burrito locations in the bay.
author: Jason G.

description: I like the chicken super burrito, but above all, the pupusas.  The hubby prefers the ham sandwich with everything you can imagine in it.  By far, I think the food is better in this location.
author: Kui T.

description: El Faro gets 5 stars.  See i'm one of those guys who LOVES El Faro and Equally loves La Taqueria.  Yes it's true...the burritos here might not be "FAT FREE", BUT MY GOODNESS are they YUMMMY in the TUMMY!  Their Chile (hot sauce for us whiteys) is incredible...it has just the right kick.   Get the Burrito...yes it's big!!! SHARE IF U MUST.   This place is  ol skool....they have a costume that Vicente Fernandez wore on stage.  If that's not an endorsement i don't know what is.  1 EXTRA STAR for having a parking lot accross the street.  Love them for that!
author: jim a.

description: Five stars for their breakfast burrito.  I love 'em.  Three stars for their regular burritos.  They're good, but I think you can find less expensive burritos that are just as good or better in the Mission.  El Faro is a great neighborhood Mexican restaurant with a friendly staff and good food.
author: Sara H.

description: well, i've wanted to try this place for a while, and when i finally tried to stop in last night at 8pm they were closed. CLOSED? What kind of restaurant closes at 8pm? That's right smack in the middle of the dinner rush I would imagine. Won't waste my time trekking out there again.
author: Amy P.

description: yuk   just had two beef tacos  meat tasted slightly "off",  bland salsa, lime wedges had seen better days,  no salsa bar and had to ask for chips & one little plastic container of some kind of salsa!!  also no beer!!    other reviewers are Right!!!   so many other better places. what's the attraction here? i ate it all, but it was not acceptable. should have sent it back!!!
author: suzanne e.

description: Not sure how or if all of the El Faro's and El Farolito's in the city are related but this has been my go-to place when I'm seriously craving a burrito.  No other location will do.  Yummy carnitas with refried beans.  Not healthy and not pretending it is but every once in a while you have to indulge.  Not sure about anything else on the menu cause this is seriously the only thing I've every eaten there.  Mmmmm, burrito...
author: Gelsomina L.

description: Delicious chicken fajita super burritos served with a friendly smile every time.
author: Sneaks N. Beat S.

description: Only if you're in the mood for a dripping wet, soggy burrito.
author: Camille H.

description: ummm maybe my tummy is el sensitivo .. but  this place was not very good .. . well it is exactly what they say it is,           fast food :-(
author: Mr. D.

description: Fantastic. Friendly, nice, sweet service.
author: N J.

description: This is a tricky one. I definitely have other places I prefer, but the siren song of the super chicken burrito still lures me to the corner of 20th and Folsom. This may have been the first SF burrito place I tried back in 1976 (or possibly the long lost Antojitos Mexicanos on Mission) when I first came here, so I have fond memories. Like how I mastered eating a burrito while bicycling to my busboy gig at MacArthur Park from SF State. What a skill! So, I admit this is no La Corneta, the food still hits a spot for old timers like me. Well, actually only the chicken burrito hits a spot. It is the sauce and the blending of the ingredients in the "super" that does it for me. As an aside, La Taqueria, on Mission near 25th, does a great taco (through all the various owners...although I must admit I like the the Warrior's fans the best, the folks who ran it in the 80's and 90's...the wife of the couple would hold up the line while Purvis Short was at the line, god what dedication to the cause of bay area hoops!) But, I, in  a major way digress. The burritos at La Taqueria suck!  If you are in SF you must use rice! Go to El Faro.Try this burrito.  This is the prototype, the gutbomb that made our fair city the burrito capitol of the world.
author: James T.

description:
i hate steamed tortillas in my burritos, so this place isn't so good. the super quesadilla is decent though. 

and in reference to one of the earlier reviews, every time i've gone they have had black beans *shrugs*
author: Joe G.

description: Well my roommate and I went here around 6 pm on a Sunday, and they seemed like they were wanting to close, but I gotta say, the burritos were really disappointing. She got a vegetarian super one, I got carne asada super no sour cream. They were just all liquid (and hers was like pure sour cream), there was no substance, and the carne asada was gristly; it's turned me off meat anew (a good thing i guess..). As a final insult, they gave us NO chips. They had them there. We could have asked I guess but it was just so weird that we wouldn't get any, I remember coming here before and getting them. I think maybe they aren't doing so well and that's what's with the cutting corners. who knows, but i couldn't finish this burrito, the stub, hours later when i was hungry again, and that's something that just does not happen with me and burritos around these parts. The gristly part seriously made me wanna hurl.
author: Kate F.
